====Usage notes====
First reading is much more common.  Like most flower names in Japanese, that reading uses Kanji for purely semantic purposes, without regards to pronunciation (a phenomenon known as ''{{w|Kanji#Special readings|Jukujikun}}''.  The characters translate literally to "purple (紫) sun (陽) flower (花)."  The second reading is a true ''{{w|Kanji#On.27yomi_.28Sino-Japanese_reading.29|On'yomi}}'' version.  Finally, because this a biological term, it is often spelled in Katakana.
